markdownRemark.html:
â€A class should only have one reason to changeâ€ is a mantra that Object-Oriented advocates have chanted for years. Dubbed the â€œSingle Responsibility Principleâ€ (SRP), it remains somewhat abstract till this day âœ¨. Abstract enough, in fact, that itâ€™s originator (Robert Martin) felt it worthwhile to explain again in a blog post - 14 years after he first wrote about it!

That blog post begins by referencing and quoting a 1972 paper, â€On the Criteria To Be Used in Decomposing Systems into Modulesâ€ by David Parnas:

â€œWe have tried to demonstrate by these examples that it is almost always incorrect to begin the decomposition of a system into modules on the basis of a flowchart.

We propose instead that one begins with a list of difficult design decisions or design decisions which are likely to change. Each module is then designed to hide such a decision from the others.â€

The paper seemed significant, as Martin wrote that the SRP appeared â€œto align with Parnasâ€™ formulationâ€. Could it demystify the SRP? What exactly was this paper about?

(Note: Iâ€™ve tried not to abstract too much of the paper, in the hope that youâ€™d be able to draw your own conclusions as well.)

The System: KWAC Index

First, Parnas sets the stage - he would compare two criteria for modularizing a system, showing that one provided superior flexibility. The system in question was a KWAC (KeyWord Alongside Context) index generator.

KWAC was an indexing system for technical manuals, allowing a reader to quickly find where in the manual a keyword was used. In addition to showing the keyword, KWAC would show the rest of the sentence as well, itâ€™s â€œcontextâ€:

To build the KWAC index, the system would take in file of sentences. For example, given the input file:

# cat input.txt
Program Development # line 1
On The Criteria # line 2

For each line, the system looked through every word, generating a KWAC entry. This was done by â€œcircularly shiftingâ€ words that came before the keyword, appending them to the end. Then, it would sort the entries alphabetically. For example, given the above file, weâ€™d get:

Criteria. On The [2] # "On The Criteria" is the original, "Criteria" was selected as the keyword here
Development. Program [1]
On The Criteria [2]
Program Development [1]
The Criteria. On [2]

The next sections explain Parnasâ€™ modularizations. This video explanation (starting from 17:16) helped me visualise and understand them, and Iâ€™ve borrowed and will continue to borrow liberally from it ğŸ™‡â€â™‚ï¸.

Modularization 1: â€œFlowchartâ€

In the first modularization, Parnas modelled the problem as a flowchart, using the individual steps to break apart the modules (an approach which Iâ€™m guilty of applying at face value):

Thereâ€™s a design flaw that isnâ€™t obvious in the diagram - all the modules rely upon common data stored with a specific layout in memory using low-level operations. Iâ€™ll contrast this with Modularization 2 later.

Hereâ€™s what each module did:

  • Input

    • Parsed the input text file (see â€œThe System: KWAC Indexâ€) and stores in memory using low-level operations. Weâ€™ll call this the in-memory â€œCharactersâ€.
    • Thereâ€™s a section of the video (23:36) that explains this, which if Iâ€™ve understood right goes something like: (1.) memory at the time was accessed in groups of 4 characters (bytes), (2.) the input was split across these groups, with spaces in between words and lines.
    • We can visualise the stored in-memory â€œCharactersâ€ as follows (Note that line breaks are not distinguished from spaces, thatâ€™s tracked separately):
    • The module also outputs â€œLinesâ€, which is an array stating the start of each line (e.g. above, Character 1 is the start of line 1, Character 21 is the start of line 2)

  • Circular Shifter

    • Accessing â€œCharactersâ€ and â€œLinesâ€, it outputs an array of â€œShiftsâ€.
    • Each â€œShiftâ€ stored the line number, as well as the starting index of each word.

  • Alphabetizer

    • Accessing â€œCharactersâ€ and â€œShiftsâ€, it sorts the â€œShiftsâ€ alphabetically and outputs them as â€œAlphabetizedâ€.

  • Output

    • Accessing â€œCharactersâ€ and â€œAlphabetizedâ€ shifts, outputs the KWAC index (see â€œThe System: KWAC Indexâ€).

A helpful visual summary of all the outputs and stored data from the video explanation:

Modularization 2: â€œInformation Hidingâ€

In this modularization, Parnas uses the criteria of â€œInformation Hidingâ€. The definition is worth mentioning for itâ€™s relevance to the SRP:

Every module in the second decomposition is characterized by its knowledge of a design decision which it hides from all others. Its interface or definition was chosen to reveal as little as possible about its inner workings.

Interestingly, what one might typically think as the general â€œresponsibilityâ€ remains the same - modules are still mostly split along the same functionality lines. Instead, the major differences that I noticed in this modularization were:

  • The details of how the characters were stored were encapsulated (hidden) via a new module, â€œLine Storageâ€. This meant that other modules did not have to know the low-level layout of the data. Instead, they would have a simpler interface to store and retrieve characters.
  • The dependencies of modules were also tweaked, such that only two modules interact directly with â€œLine Storageâ€, as opposed to every module having to access â€œCharactersâ€ in Modularization 1.
  • Modules in Modularization 1 depended on outputs from previous modules or common in-memory data. In contrast, modules in Modularization 2 depended directly on the interface of other modules (similar to calling methods on the module, a more Object-Oriented style).

Each module in greater detail:

  • Input

    • Like Modularization 1, also parses the input file, but this time initializes a â€œLine Storageâ€ and inserts the data.

  • Line Storage

    • Think of it like an Object that has methods for inserting and retrieving characters by line (e.g. get Character 5 of Line 1, Word 2).
    • Note: Unlike Modularization 1, this means callers do not need to know the nitty-gritty details of how data is stored.

  • Circular Shifter

    • Generates the circular shifts from Line Storage in an initialization step.
    • Instead of outputting â€œShiftsâ€, the module itself provides an interface (like an Object) similar to Line Storage, but allows retrieval of characters by their shifts instead of lines (e.g. get Character 5 of Shift 1, Word 2).

  • Alphabetizer

    • Retrieving the characters from Circular Shifter, this modules sorts by alphabet and remembers the shifts in an initialization step.
    • Instead of outputting the â€œAlphabetizedâ€ shifts, the module also provides an interface for getting ordered Circular Shifts indexes (e.g. tell me the shift number thatâ€™s in the 2nd sorted position).

  • Output

    • Uses Alphabetizer and Circular Shifter to generate the KWAC Index.

Comparison: Changeability

While other comparisons were made, the analysis of changeability speaks most to the SRP. Parnas begins by suggesting some â€œlikelyâ€ change scenarios. Most require many modules to be updated in Modularization 1, but have a much smaller blast radius in Modularization 2.

Letâ€™s take Scenario B below as an example - since all the modules in Modularization 1 depended upon a specific layout of â€œCharactersâ€ in memory, changing that layout would require changing every module. However, in Modularization 2, this would only require a change in the implementation of â€œLine Storageâ€ - the interface could stay the same, meaning other modules were shielded from this change!

Scenario Modularization 1 Modularization 2
A. Deciding to store â€œCharactersâ€ in a different medium (e.g. filesystem) instead of memory All modules Line Storage
B. Deciding on a different way to store the â€œCharactersâ€ (e.g. group by words instead of every 4 characters) All Modules Line Storage
C. Deciding to store the full sentences of each circular shift instead of their indexes Circular Shifter, Alphabetizer, Output Circular Shifter
D. Deciding to change â€œAlphabetizedâ€ generation to be lazy or distributed (possibly due to a large dataset?) Difficult to achieve as computation must be completed before output Achievable as Output doesnâ€™t need all the shifts to be â€œalphabetizedâ€

So the takeaway here is that good â€œinformation hidingâ€ (a.k.a the SRP) results in a system that adapts more easily to changes.

Conclusion

So where does the paper leave us in relation to the SRP? Personally, I left with a better understanding of why it was important - it should result in a system that is easier to evolve with changes in requirements. However, even with the (helpful) example, we donâ€™t get a magic formula for applying the SRP - it remains more art than science.

Whatâ€™s your framework for beginning â€œwith a list of difficult design decisions or design decisions which are likely to changeâ€?

frontmatter.title: A 1972 paper and the Single Responsibility Principle
frontmatter.description: While trying to explain the Single Responsibility Principle, it's originator calls attention to the paper 'On the Criteria To Be Used in Decomposing Systems into Modules'. Why was this paper so significant? Let's find out!
